comment._content: The picture it's nice so beautiful

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
Looking in Trove, there is a Family Notice (Births)  in the Courier Mail of 22 January 1938:
BLUNCK.— At Beaudesert, on Thursday. January 13 to Mr. and Mrs. Rex Blunck (nee Clarice Johnson), a son (Barry Johnson).
On 8 October 1934, in the Courier Mail, this: A concert in aid of the Ballandean School of Arts building fund was organised by Mr. Frank Fielder, assisted by Mrs. Denyer. Items were contributed by Mrs. Denyer, Misses P. and V. Denyer, E. Mason, Clarice Johnson, and Messrs. Frank Fielder, L. Watts, Douglas Watts, and George Fisher. A dance followed the concert, music being supplied by Mrs. Denyer, Misses K. Newman and Walsh, and Messrs. R. C. R. Newman and Dudley Smith.
There is a birth registration in 1912, in country Queensland, for a Clarice Maud Johnston.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
The birth  of a Reginald Russell Hartigan was registered in country Queensland in 1912. Nothing much else pops out with a quick search.

Widening the search on Clarice, she pops up a few times in reports of social events at Stanthorpe in 1926 and 1930; she appears to have been in the Stanthorpe Amateur Dramatic Society.

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/96752972@N00] Thanks for the additional information you added to this photograph. Trove is indeed a great source for this kind of information. It's a great help to us at slq to have more context added to our collection material. Keep up the great work!

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content: I suppose the other way of looking at it is that I'm just a 'stickybeak'. I can't see something like this without trying to find out something about the people. (I do research for the Sandgate and District Historical Society, plus I am slowly working through my grandfather's collection of World War 1 photos and other ephemera to try to add more details to the little he left me.) Have you had a look at HistoryPin? www.historypin.com/

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/96752972@N00] Stickybeak is just another word for researcher we say.  We love HistoryPin too. Looking at contributing some of our collections to it in 2012. Would love to know more about your grandfather's collection. There is so much buzz internationally in the library and museum world about the 100 year anniversary of the beginning of World War 1.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content: When Grandad met the girl who was to become my Grandma (while on leave in England) they both bought cameras. Grandad took photos in France, Wiltshire, Middlesex, and on the ship (TSS Wiltshire) home. Also, around Moreton Bay in 1919-1920 to show Grandma what she was coming to. Some prints he sent to Grandma and she brought them out with her after they were married in 1920. So, sometimes I am lucky in that I have the negative, a print, and an annotated print that has been sent to 'the girlfriend'. Grandma also took photos of her family in Middlesex and Devon, but they are far less well documented. My intention is to, eventually, donate the negatives to the State Library once I can confidently identify and locate them all on a map. I will send you a flickr mail showing you where you can find some of these photos on the internet. I do have a few in my flickr photostream. I just had a 'win' this morning, as Swindon Museum helped me locate one batch of photographs. They are here in their correct location: www.historypin.com/collections/view/id/8230076/title/GWR%...
